title: Blatter denies scandal responsibility
desc: Fifa president Sepp Blatter says he cannot be held responsible for the current corruption scandal but vows to work to earn back trust.

title: Putin makes troop deaths state secret
desc: President Vladimir Putin declares Russian troop losses in peacetime a state secret as the Kremlin continues to deny sending troops to Ukraine.

title: Lenovo phone beams virtual keyboard
desc: Chinese electronics giant Lenovo has unveiled a phone with a built-in laser projector that can be used to display a virtual keyboard or display.

title: IS 'kills 20 men at Palmyra site'
desc: Islamic State militants killed 20 men at the ancient theatre at the Unesco World Heritage site of Palmyra central Syria a monitoring group says.

title: Most-wanted Nazi 'unfit for trial'
desc: Former SS lieutenant Gerhard Sommer at the top of a most-wanted list of Nazis has been declared unfit for trial by prosecutors in Germany.

title: Cameron's EU exit warning to leaders
desc: UK PM David Cameron starts a tour of European capitals as a bill paving the way for the UK's EU referendum is launched.

title: US charges Chinese in testing scam
desc: The US Department of Justice has charged 15 Chinese nationals with developing a scheme to have imposters take university entrance exams.

title: Libor trader pledged 'humongous deal'
desc: The trader at the centre of the Libor rate-rigging trial offered his contact a humongous deal to keep the rate low a court hears.

title: Zuma not liable for home upgrades
desc: South African President Jacob Zuma will not have to repay state money spent to upgrade his private home in Nkandla the police minister says.

title: Tajik special ops chief 'joins IS'
desc: Tajikistan's special forces chief appears in a video claiming to have joined Islamic State forces in Syria.

title: MEPs in new EU-US trade controversy
desc: MEPs call for transparent and public handling of trade disputes with the US but soften their stance on controversial commercial courts.

title: Google to add 'buy button'
desc: Google has confirmed that it is to introduce a buy button to its search results imminently.

title: VIDEO: Putin shows his support for Blatter
desc: Russian President Vladimir Putin has accused the US of trying to block Sepp Blatter from being re-elected as Fifa president.

title: VIDEO: Why brave treacherous Bay of Bengal?
desc: The BBC's Justin Rowlatt travelled to Teknaf on the southern coast of Bangladesh from where hundreds of migrants begin the perilous journey across the Bay of Bengal.

title: VIDEO: 'Diblings' - the siblings created through donors
desc: Being a 'dibling' - a child biologically connected through egg or sperm donation can lead to a large family of half brothers and sisters as the Victoria Derbyshire programme finds out.

title: VIDEO: Meeting the Mayfair squatters
desc: A group squatting in a building in London's Mayfair have been ordered to leave the property following a ruling by the High Court.

title: VIDEO: Why children love the # symbol
desc: Hashtag has been declared children's word of the year by the Oxford University Press.

title: VIDEO: Police recruits get tough in Ukraine
desc: David Stern visited the police academy in Ukraine where new police officers are being trained as part of a major programme of reforms to the service.

title: VIDEO: Street workout to get SA children fit
desc: South African street workout competitor Smith Mangena is taking the sport back to the townships to keep young people healthy.

title: VIDEO: Why the Common Dolphin is becoming more common
desc: The BBC's John Maguire joins a scientific expedition that is studying the Common Dolphin population off the west coast of Scotland and trying to find out why until recently it was quite a rare sight.

title: A football drama fans could do without
desc: The BBC's North American editor Jon Sopel says Fifa head Sepp Blatter is a known quantity for all the wrong reasons.

title: Bahrain: Between rebellion and reform
desc: Bahrain seemed to be on the brink of revolution in 2011 - but has that spark now been extinguished asks Frank Gardner.

title: Hillary's 'everyday pantsuit tee'
desc: Campaign-themed products aren't limited to bumper stickers and yard signs any more. But is there a secret strategy behind Rand Paul's filibuster starter pack and Hillary Clinton's pantsuit t-shirt?

title: Why the Americans took on Fifa
desc: America doesn't even like football they say so why does it want to clean it up for the world?

title: Android app age ratings grow up
desc: Later this week Google will hand over control of its Play store's Android app ratings to a third-party.

title: Russian gas industry looks east
desc: Despite sanctions and low prices Russia's gas industry is in surprisingly good health not least due to closer ties with China.

title: Swiss cheese hole origins solved
desc: Scientists say they have discovered why Swiss cheese has holes in it: apparently it is all down to how dirty buckets are when the milk is collected.

title: India's Mysore crowns new maharaja
desc: A 23-year-old graduate from the University of Massachusetts is crowned the new maharaja of Mysore titular head of the 600-year-old Wadiyar dynasty.

title: Honda Fiat and BMW in airbag recall
desc: Three major carmakers have expanded recalls of vehicles with faulty Takata airbags.

title: Ireland votes through Aer Lingus deal
desc: The Republic of Ireland's parliament has approved the sale of the nation's 25% stake in Aer Lingus to British Airways owner IAG.

title: Google gives first peek at Android M
desc: Google reveals easier-to-control privacy permissions greater support for fingerprint sensors and longer battery life in the next version of Android.

title: GoPro to make a quadcopter drone
desc: The action camera-maker GoPro reveals plans to make its own quadcopter drone and also unveils kit to aid virtual reality filmmakers.

title: BB King honoured with procession
desc: Blues artist BB King has been honoured with a street procession in Memphis a fortnight after his death at the age of 89.

title: Top Gear car plate complaints rejected
desc: The BBC Trust rejects complaints over Top Gear's Patagonia special in which a car number plate appeared to refer to the Falklands conflict.

title: Black hole seen 'playing billiards'
desc: A series of images captures two vast blobs of plasma shot out by a black hole cannoning into each other in a nearly light-speed cosmic collision.

title: Earliest evidence of human violence
desc: A human skull from a deep cave in northern Spain shows evidence of a lethal violent attack 430000 years ago a study shows.

title: Pocket optician 'good as eye charts'
desc: A smartphone app is as effective at testing eyesight as an optician's clinic a trial suggests.

title: 'Give HIV drugs at diagnosis'
desc: HIV drugs should be given at the moment of diagnosis according to a major trial that could change the way the disease is treated.

title: Blatter wants to stay as Fifa boss
desc: Sepp Blatter refuses to resign as Fifa president and vows to stay to restore trust in the scandal-hit organisation.

title: Murray tested but into third round
desc: Andy Murray beats Portugal's Joao Sousa in four sets to secure his place in the French Open third round.

title: Who killed Alberto Nisman?
desc: Argentine prosecutor Alberto Nisman was found dead in a pool of blood in his bathroom in January - Wyre Davies examines the evidence and asks who might have wanted to kill him?

title: How did my dad's Uber account get hacked?
desc: Thousands of users of taxi app Uber have reported their accounts being hacked or hijacked. What's going on?

title: Pussy Galore back in new Bond novel
desc: Pussy Galore is to be reunited with James Bond in an official new 007 novel by Anthony Horowitz.

title: Iran leader shrine 'too extravagant'
desc: Critics say project goes against late leader's principles.

title: SA denies organising World Cup bribe
desc: South African officials dismiss US allegations that a $10m (£6.5m) bribe was organised for top Fifa officials in order to host the 2010 World Cup.

title: Concern over Mers spread in S Korea
desc: Concern is growing in South Korea over the spread of the Mers virus after a man defied quarantine to travel to China.

title: Frenchwoman jailed for man's torture
desc: A 43-year-old woman who enslaved and abused her ex-boyfriend in her Paris flat for more than a year is jailed for 18 months.

title: Venezuela and Rosneft agree oil deal
desc: Venezuela and Russian oil giant Rosneft agree to invest $14bn (£9.2) in Venezuela's oil and gas sector Venezuelan leader Nicolas Maduro says.

title: Al-Nusra 'told not to attack West'
desc: Al-Qaeda has ordered its affiliate in Syria not to use the country to launch attacks on the West the leader of al-Nusra Front says.

title: US lighthouse moves inland
desc: The Gay Head Lighthouse in Martha's Vineyard Massachusetts its being moved inland on Thursday to avoid falling into the Atlantic ocean.

title: Rail workers to strike twice in June
desc: Rail workers in the RMT union are to hold 24-hour and 48-hour strikes next month after rejecting a pay offer from Network Rail.

title: Galloway to run for London mayor
desc: Controversial former MP George Galloway says he will seek election as the next mayor of London.

title: Food bug 'found in 73% of chickens'
desc: Nearly three-quarters of fresh shop-bought chickens test positive for food poisoning bug campylobacter in year-long study.

title: Syria girls have 'contacted family'
desc: Three schoolgirls from London who are feared to have joined Islamic State in Syria have made contact with their families their lawyer says.

title: In pictures: Edinburgh Fringe poster contest
desc: Who won? The official poster for the 2015 festival

title: Eurovision Song Contest: In pictures
desc: Party time at the 60th song contest in Vienna

desc: Rare access - an Indian high court at work

desc: Ben Weller has been taking pictures of South Korea's markets

desc: Palestinians press Fifa to suspend Israel from football

desc: Can Nigeria's new leader end corruption without a horse whip?

desc: What Australia isn't telling its unwanted refugees
